The "Hidden Rate Elimination Act of 2001" is introduced, amending the 1986 Internal Revenue Code. It specifies that changes in tax rates under this Act will not be considered as changes in tax rates for certain purposes. Additionally, there is a reduction in marginal income tax rates for individuals. The "Hidden Rate Elimination Act of 2001" amends the 1986 Internal Revenue Code, reducing marginal income tax rates for individuals in 2002. Married individuals filing joint returns and surviving spouses are subject to the new tax rates. The tax rates for individuals in 2002 based on taxable income are as follows:
- Not over $12,000: 14% of taxable income
- Over $12,000 but not over $45,200: $1,680 plus 15% of the excess over $12,000
- Over $45,200 but not over $109,250: $6,660 plus 27% of the excess over $45,200
- Over $109,250 but not over $166,450: $23,953.50 plus 30% of the excess over $109,250
- Over $166,450 but not over $297,300: $41,113.50 plus 35% of the excess over $166,450
- Over $297,300: $86,911 plus 38% of the excess The tax imposed on the taxable income of heads of households is $86,911 plus 38% of the excess over $297,300. Tax rates based on taxable income:
